NEWS BITES

Developers Eye New Indonesian Capital As Indonesia begins plans to shift its capital from Jakarta to an area on the island of Borneo, amid Jakarta’s dramatic environmental disaster, property developers are flocking to Borneo to take advantage of the new influx of growth in the city. Property companies that have buildings underway in the region are now touting their accessibility to the new capital, the construction of which will begin in 2020. South China Morning Post

Study Eyeballs Property Price Drop Under No-Deal Brexit New research predicts that if a Brexit deal is not reached by the Oct. 31 deadline, property prices in London could drop as much as 7%. If a deal is reached for the U.K. to leave the European Union, prices will fall 4.7%, according to a report from KPMG. The research says that on the extreme end, prices could plummet as much as 10% to 20%. City A.M.

Australian Prices Grew in August August home prices in Australia grew by the highest monthly rate in two years, after a long period of tumult. Prices rose 1% in the capital cities with Sydney at 1.6% and Melbourne at 1.4%. They increased by 0.8% for the whole nation. National prices hadn’t seen positive growth since October of 2017. Cut interest rates helped fuel growth. The Business Times

Chinese Buyers Look to France Chinese interest in French real estate grew in 2019’s first quarter with Chinese nationals becoming the largest group of foreign buyers, a title previously held by Italy. The country has been rising in popularity since 2014, as rental income is steady and lucrative, mortgage rates are low and Paris does not have restrictions on purchases by foreigners. South China Morning Post

Dubai Looking to Limit New Construction Amid dropping property prices, Dubai’s Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum is looking to slow down the pace of new construction. In the first six months of this year, prices were 12% lower than they were in 2017. At the same time, 21,000 new units were introduced, with 38,400 more units planned for the rest of the year. Sheikh Mohammed is creating a committee that will look at the pace of new construction. The Associated Press

Anne Heche, James Tupper List Lake Arrowhead Home Anne Heche and her former partner James Tupper are selling a vacation property in Lake Arrowhead, California, for $1.05 million. The 1956 waterside cottage comes with a dock and a patio overlooking the lake. It has three bedrooms and 1,440 square feet of living space. The retreat was purchased by Mr. Tupper in 2013 for $899,000. Los Angeles Times
